frameDefinitions: These words refer to Parts merging to form a Whole.
A Mass_theme, generally made up of many individuals, moves from a Source to a Goal with some Path.
Two (or more) people (the Interlocutors, also encodable as Interlocutor_1 and Interlocutor_2) talk to one another.
An Agent suddenly and often violently separates the Whole_patient into two or more smaller Pieces, resulting in the Whole_patient no longer existing as such.
In this frame a group of Individuals meet to form a Configuration.
These words refer to an Agent joining Parts to form a Whole.
frameExamples: The two droplets <t>merge</t>, and then travel down the windowpane even faster.
Emails from so-called Nigerian princes <t>flooded</t> inboxes all over the US.
I would rather <t>discuss</t> politics with anyone but him.
He <t>ripped</t> <t>up</t> the letter faster than you can say 'Jack Robbins'. INI
The crowd <t>came together</t> in the courtyard.
listRoleDefinitions: The entities that merge to form a single <fen>Whole</fen>.
The single, undifferentiated entity that is the result of the amalgamation.
The prominent entity that combines with <fen>Part_2</fen> to form a <fen>Whole</fen>.
The less focussed-upon entity that the <fen>Part_1</fen> merges with.
The time at which the <fen>Parts</fen> become amalgamated into a <fen>Whole</fen>
The location at which the amalgamation occurs.
The mass of entities which moves.
The place where the overall motion event takes place, thus including Source, Path, and Goal locations.
The Source is the location the Theme occupies initially before its change of location.
Path refers to (a part of the) ground the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> travels over or to a landmark the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> travels by.
Goal is the location the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> ends up in.

This role is used for expressions that indicate motion along a line from the deitic center towards a reference point (which may be implicit) that is neither the <fen>Goal</fen> of the posture change nor a landmark along the way of the moving part of the body.  Often <fen>Direction</fen> is defined with reference to the canonical orientation of the <fen>Mass_theme</fen>, or the orientation imposed by an implicit observer.
When the event occurs.
The spatial setting in which the Mass_motion takes place.

In cases where the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, this role identifies the conversational participant with greater semantic and syntactic prominence, as compared with <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen>. That is, <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen> is generally encoded as Subject, and peripheral FEs that do not make reference to the event itself generally make reference to <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen>.  Thus a <fen>Purpose</fen> (or <fen>Means</fen>, <fen>Depictive</fen>, or <fen>Manner</fen>) is construed to be that of <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen>, not necessarily that of <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen> or the group of <fen>Interlocutors</fen> as a whole.

In cases where the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen> refers to the semantically and grammatically less prominent group.  It is generally encoded within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by <ment>with</ment>).  Note that it is possible for a single role to correspond to multiple referents. For example, if the prepositional object in the example below were plural, we would still assign it the single role <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen>.

In some sentences both participants are expressed by the Subject, and there is no 'with'-phrase (cf example 1). In sentences like this, the Subject is assigned the role role <fen>Interlocutors</fen>. In such sentences, the Subject always denotes more than one person, and it is understood that the reciprocal communication takes place between these two (or more) people. The Subject may denote two or more people either through conjunction, as in example 1, or through plurality, as in example 2, or by denoting a group, as in example 3. In each of these cases the role <fen>Interlocutors</fen> is assigned. Notice that for nouns in the Discussion frame, it is possible for the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> role to be expressed by a prepositional phrase as in example 4.

<fen>Topic</fen> expresses the subject that the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> are trying to come to some agreement about.  It may refer, for example, to an undesirable issue that the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> want to have the proper response to, or it may refer more directly to an unresolved question.
The time at which the discussion takes place.
The location at which a discussion takes place.
The conscious entity, generally a person, that performs the intentional action that results in the <fen>Whole_patient</fen> being broken into <fen>Pieces</fen>.
The entity which is destroyed by the <fen>Agent</fen> and that ends up broken into <fen>Pieces</fen>.
The fragments of the <fen>Whole_patient</fen> that result from the <fen>Agent</fen>'s action.
An event which leads to the fragmentation of the <fen>Whole_patient</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> breaks up the <fen>Whole_patient</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Agent</fen> breaks the <fen>Whole_patient</fen> into pieces.
The <fen>Individuals</fen> are self-movers who come together.
The <fen>Configuration</fen> describes the resulting formation of the individuals.
<fen>Party_1</fen> is the grammatically more prominent participant in the congregating event.
A grammatically less prominent participant in the congregating event.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the congregating occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the congregating occurs.

In causative uses of these verbs there is an <fen>Agent</fen> responsible for amalgamating the <fen>Parts</fen>. The <fen>Agent</fen> is generally the External Argument (or the object of a PP-by in passives).
This  role identifies <fen>Whole</fen> as the entity resulting from combination of <fen>Parts</fen>.  When overtly expressed, it is usually a PP Complement (often headed by into).
This role identifies the <fen>Parts</fen> entities being combined, and is often expressed in a single plural NP, usually the direct object of a verb.
This role identifies the first of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. It  is most often the NP-Object of a verb.
This role identifies the second of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. It is usually a PP Complement.
The time at which the amalgamation occurs.
The location that the event occurs.
listRoleExamples: They had all just merged <fex>into one big file</fex>.
<fex>The single smaller soul</fex> merges with the Ur-soul.
The single smaller soul merges <fex>with the Ur-soul</fex>.
Letters streamed in <fex>all over the country</fex>.
Afterwards, the crowd flooded <fex>away from the ceremony</fex>.
The door opened , and a crowd of people flooded <fex>past me</fex>, into the hall.
Eager spectators crowded <fex>into the auditorium</fex>
<fex>In the main auditorium</fex> people crowded around Orange's newest computer
<fex>The President</fex> conferred with his top advisor.
The President debated <fex>with his top advisor</fex>.
(1) <fex>The President and his advisor</fex> discussed the Venezuelan situation briefly before the summit.
The President and his top advisors discussed <fex>the scandal</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex> the participants discussed taking down the last trade barriers without consensus.
We just conferred for a couple of hours <fex>up in her room</fex>.
<fex>I and I alone</fex> can shatter the gem and break the curse.
Shattering someone's confidence is a little different than shattering <fex>a dish</fex>.
I smashed the toy boat <fex>to flinders</fex>.
<fex>The crowd</fex> gathered on the streets of Paris.
<fex>Our group</fex> met with theirs in the plaza.
Our group met <fex>with theirs</fex> in the plaza.
<fex>The chef</fex> combined the ingredients.
Chuck merged the corpora <fex>into a database</fex>.
Chuck merged <fex>the corpora</fex> into a database.
The workmen joined <fex>the annex</fex> to the main building.
The workkmen joined the annex <fex>to the main building</fex>.
